passage_text: Many animals have body symmetry with distinct front and back ends. This type of symmetry is A. unilateral symmetry. B. bilateral symmetry. C. asymmetry. D. radi
Many animals have body symmetry with distinct front and back ends. This type of symmetry is bilateral symmetry. Animals with bilateral symmetry have one line that divides them into two mirror images.

A few animals, including most sponges, have no symmetry. Depending on their symmetry, animals share some general characteristics. Animals with radial symmetry have body parts that are arranged in a circular pattern around a central point, like spokes on a bicycle wheel. They do not have distinct front or back ends.
